metadata.title: Dysphagia Assessment  Modified Barium Swallow (Pediatrics)
description: A modified barium swallow study (MBSS) is a recorded (either on videotape or digital media) fluoroscopic examination of a patient’s swallowing function performed by a speech-language  pathologist (SLP) in conjunction with a radiologist during which a patient is asked to swallow varying amounts of barium mixtures.(1,2) The MBSS is used to identify oropharyngeal dysphagia as well as the patient’s risk for aspiration.(1,2) Additionally, the SLP might utilize the MBSS to determine and to teach appropriate compensatory strategies and/or therapeutic exercises for a patient with dysphagia(1,2)

For pediatric patients, the MBSS will be used not only to diagnose dysphagia, but to examine any infant/child feeding disorder as well(3) –Behavioral feeding disorders include taste or texture aversions and food avoidances; these types of feeding disorders might be present in children with or without an underlying organic dysphagia(3) –An MBSS is one part of an extensive, multidisciplinary evaluation of infants and children with feeding difficulties(3)
A barium swallow procedure is a test to examine esophageal anatomy and physiology; the barium swallow is not the same test as an MBSS(4)
The term MBSS is interchangeable with both VFSS and VSE; these descriptions all refer to the same procedure
indications: An MBSS is indicated in pediatric patients with dysphagia and/or other feeding disorders

Indicated in certain patients with dysphagia based on the outcome of an in-depth  clinical swallow examination (CSE) –An in-depth  CSE should always precede an MBSS.(2) For detailed information on a CSE, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia Assessment: In-depth  Clinical Swallow Examination (Pediatrics)  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709064
An MBSS might be part of a comprehensive medical workup if a physician is attempting to determine a patient’s underlying diagnosis
Indicated for infants and children with slow weight gain or weight loss and/or observed difficulty feeding(3)
Indicated if a child presents with unexplained history of weight loss with no known diagnosis or subjective complaints of difficulty swallowing(5)
reimbursement: Reimbursement for procedure will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this procedure Indications for procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Prior to an MBSS, ensure that the patient is not on NPO status (nothing by mouth) awaiting a procedure; check with patient’s nurse prior to start of examination

Review the patient’s chart and speak to the patient’s nurse and family members if possible to rule out food allergies; if a patient has a food allergy, ensure that if food and liquid are mixed with the barium for trials in MBSS, they do not contain these allergens(15)
In addition to food allergies, inquire about any religious or cultural dietary restrictions prior to giving the patient anything to eat(18)

For a pediatric MBSS, the SLP must ensure that the foods and/or liquids presented during the examination are developmentally appropriate (e.g., not presenting solid food trials to infants under 4 months of age)

Observe universal precautions with every patient during dysphagia assessments; take note of any additional precautions required for specific patients (i.e., airborne, droplet, or contact precautions)(1,18)
Stay with the patient during the entirety of the MBSS. Do NOT leave the patient alone with food or drink until the MBSS is complete and the patient is determined to be safe for oral feeding(18)
Following the MBSS, the infant or child’s head should be elevated to an angle greater than 30° for 30–45  minutes to prevent reflux-related  aspiration(1)
Any clinician performing an MBSS should be trained in the Heimlich maneuver as well as CPR, as choking is a possible complication of an MBSS(18)

If and when aspiration of barium contrast occurs during an MBSS, proceed with caution; patients with significantly compromised respiratory function might not be able to tolerate any aspiration safely(1) –Refer to specific clinic/hospital policies and procedures for how to continue an MBSS once aspiration has occurred(1) –For most patients, small amounts of aspirated barium contrast will not harm the patient; however, each institution has policies related to the acceptable amount of aspirated barium contrast(1)

indications for procedure: Dysphagia Dysphagia is the term that refers to difficulty swallowing and/or a swallowing disorder(6,7) Complications of dysphagia include malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration and aspiration pneumonia, and death(6,8,9,39) There are two main categories of dysphagia(7) –Oropharyngeal dysphagia  (7,10,11) -Dysphagia involving either the oral and/or pharyngeal phase of swallowing -Dysphagia that affects the oral phase only is referred to as oral dysphagia(12) -Dysphagia that affects the pharyngeal phase only is referred to as pharyngeal dysphagia(12) -Dysphagia that affects both oral and pharyngeal phases of the swallow is referred to as oropharyngeal dysphagia(12) -Symptoms of oropharyngeal dysphagia include choking and/or coughing while eating and/or drinking, pocketing food in the cheeks, and loss of food or liquid from the mouth while attempting to swallow(6,10) –Esophageal dysphagia  (7,10,11) -Dysphagia resulting from an impairment of the esophagus or lower esophageal sphincter -Patients generally report symptoms such as regurgitation or heartburn(6,10,11) -Although an MBSS is not the primary examination for diagnosing esophageal dysphagia,if clinically indicated the SLP and radiologist can perform an esophageal sweep during the MBSS to screen for esophageal dysphagia in order to make an appropriate referral for further diagnostic workup(30,41) For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic Pediatric patients at risk for dysphagia: Dysphagia in infants and children might occur because of behavioral, developmental, or neurological conditions as well as respiratory problems, GERD, or structural issues(13) –Children with the following diagnoses are at an elevated risk for dysphagia: -Brain tumor/brainstem tumor(14) -Stroke(14) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with stroke, see Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Post-Stroke : CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708770) -Craniofacial abnormalities (such as cleft lip and/or palate)(13,14) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia as a result of cleft lip and/or palate, see  Clinical Review ... Feeding Disorders: Infants with Cleft Lip and Palate  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708978) -CHARGE syndrome(13) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with CHARGE syndrome, see  Clinical Review ... Feeding Disorders: CHARGE Syndrome  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708992) -PierreRobin sequence(13) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with PierreRobin sequence, see  Clinical Review ... Feeding Disorders: Infants with Pierre Robin Sequence  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708984) -Down syndrome(36) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with Down syndrome, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia: Infants and Children with Down Syndrome  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709051) -Ear, nose, throat, or maxillofacial surgery(15) -Failure to thrive(13) -Genetic syndromes(34) -GERD(13,14)  -Head and neck cancer(6,7) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with head and neck cancer, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia: Patients with Head and Neck Cancer  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709050) -Infection(7) -Botulism(7) -Diphtheria(7) -Lyme disease(7) -Syphilis(7) -Laryngomalacia (“soft larynx”; delay of maturation of the larynx and surrounding structures)(35,38,42) -Neurological conditions(6,7,13,15) -Arnold-Chiari  malformation(14) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with Chiari malformation, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia: Chiari Malformation  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709104) -Cerebral palsy(37,40)(for detailed information on assessment and treatment of children with cerebral palsy, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia: Cerebral Palsy (Children)  ); CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708945) -Dermatomyositis/polymyositis(7) -Fetal alcohol syndrome(13) (for detailed information on fetal alcohol syndrome, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic) -Intellectual disability(4) -Muscular dystrophy(7,14) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of children with muscular dystrophy, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia: Congenital Myotonic Dystrophy  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709088 and Clinical Review ... Dysphagia: Duchenne's Muscular Dystrophy  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709070) -Pervasive developmental delay(14) -Prematurity (born prior to 37 weeks’ gestational age)(13,14) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of premature infants, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia: Preterm Infants  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708937) -Prior cervical, cardiothoracic, or esophageal surgery(7,15) -Prolonged endotracheal intubation(16) -Tracheotomy or ventilator dependence(13) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in children with tracheostomy tubes, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia: Children with Tracheostomy  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709082) -Traumatic brain injury (TBI)(7,11,13) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in children with TBI, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia: Traumatic Brain Injury in Pediatric Patients  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709008)

According to the guideline from the American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria (ACR AC) for dysphagia, an MBSS should be the first choice for a diagnostic examination in cases of oropharyngeal dysphagia with an attributable cause.(29) In cases of oropharyngeal dysphagia with an unknown cause, an MBSS is sometimes recommended as part of the diagnostic workup; however, static X-rays  of pharyngeal anatomy as well as a biphasic esophageal X-ray  examination would typically be performed first(29)

Aspiration:  An MBSS is one of the instrumental examinations of swallowing that is able to identify aspiration(1,13) Aspiration occurs when food or liquid penetrates below the level of the vocal folds Normally, aspiration of food or liquid would provoke a cough reflex. In many infants and children with dysphagia, the cough response is not elicited; this is known as silent aspiration(43) –An MBSS is very useful for identifying silent aspiration as it is impossible to determine if a patient is silently aspirating with a noninstrumental CSE alone(1,13)

contrast preparation: Any trial given during an MBSS should be either completely comprised of barium (in consistencies of thin liquid, as wellas slightly thick, mildly thick, and moderately thick liquids per International Dysphagia Diet Standardisation Initiative(IDDSI) flow test, and/or pill) or food and liquid mixed with barium(32)
Only barium or food/liquid mixed with barium will be visible as contrast on the MBSS(1)

Low-viscosity  liquid barium suspensions (thin barium) are usually prepared with a density of 1.0 g/mL(1)–Adding barium to a food or liquid usually does not change the overall viscosity; however, the SLP must pay closeattention to the viscosity of the food and liquid trials once preparation of the trials is complete to ensure accuratediagnosis of dysphagia(1)
positioning: positioning infants and chi: Generally, it is best to position infants and children with the least amount of upheaval(17)
Parent/caregiver should be asked to bring the child’s regular feeding/highchair or wheelchair so that the feeding positionused at home might be replicated(17)
Infants can be placed in a car seat, propped up with pillows and/or blankets, or seated in commercially available infantfeeding seats made for radiographic studies(17)

Having a parent or caregiver hold the infant during the MBSS might help to calm the child during the study; however, thisshould be used only as a last resort because it exposes the adult to unnecessary radiation(17)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Does the patient have a diagnosis that places him or her at an elevated risk for dysphagia?(5)

course of treatment.medical management: Note current and previous medical management of dysphagia diagnosis and/or other medical conditions; do any of the medical treatments place the patient at an elevated risk for dysphagia? Document any current or previous ear, nose, throat, maxillofacial, cervical, or esophageal surgery/procedures as these increase risk of dysphagia(7,15)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Review the patient’s medical record to determine if a CSE or an instrumental evaluation of the swallow was completed during a previous hospital stay or outpatient visit
Review neuroimaging results such as MRI and CT scan
Review the patient’s recent chest X-rays;  be aware of increasing infiltrates in the lungs
Chronic lung infections might be an indication of aspiration/dysphagia(13)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., modified bottle nipples or changing feeding position) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help Children with prior histories of dysphagia might already be using an altered diet prior to admission to hospital/ clinic(20)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for dysphagia or another speech/language deficit and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -with specific foods (e.g., particular textures, flavors, temperatures)? -with specific meals?  -starting halfway through the meal? -If the child becomes fatigued during meals, this might increase the risk of aspiration(13) -when he or she is distracted or having a meal with a group of people?(9) -Is there something specific the parent does that makes feeding/mealtimes easier or more efficient?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms -For older children who complain of difficulty swallowing, what exactly is the problem with swallowing? -Does food stick in the throat?(11) -Does the child cough and/or choke while eating or drinking? -Is there pain associated with swallowing?
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables -When did the symptoms of dysphagia first present?(21) -How frequently does the patient experience the symptoms of dysphagia?(21)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Does difficulty swallowing saliva and/or secretions interfere with patient’s ability to sleep? -Document number of wakings/night
history of present illness.respiratory status: Patients with a compromised respiratory status are at higher risk of complications (such as aspiration pneumonia) due to dysphagia(18,20) -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula?(15) -Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube?(15) -When the patient has an uncapped tracheostomy tube, subglottic pressure is reduced and the strength of the swallow is altered(18) -Complete Passy-Muir  tracheostomy and ventilator swallowing and speaking valve (PMV) evaluation prior to the MBSS (for detailed information on assessment and treatment with the Passy-Muir valve, see  Clinical Review ...T708919) -If the patient has a PMV , food and liquid trials might be presented with and without the valve in place during the MBSS in order for the SLP to determine the benefit of the PMV for each specific patient -Does the patient require ventilator support? -Patients who required intubation/ventilator support are at an elevated risk for aspiration during swallowing(18,26) -Patient should be extubated at least 24 to 48 hours prior to completion of an MBSS to allow for the reduction of laryngeal edema and improved vocal fold function(27,28) -Infants and children with prolonged need for ventilator or tracheostomy might develop dysphagia due to decreased sensation and muscle strength in the larynx(3) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________ History intake specific to infant/pediatric feeding disorder population How long do feedings take with the child?(3) -If child’s parents report feeding sessions that routinely last longer than 2530  minutes, this might indicate a feeding or swallowing problem Does the child become irritable or lethargic during feedings/mealtimes?(3) How much assistance is required during meals? Is the child completely dependent on others for feeding?(3) -If the child requires more assistance than is appropriate given his or her age, this places the child at higher risk for silent aspiration(3) -Older children requiring total assistance for feeding generally present with some type of physical or mental impairment (such as cerebral palsy)(3) Are there types of food that the child avoids?(3) -If a child refuses to eat certain foods or certain types of foods, this might be a result of aspiration, gastrointestinal, or sensorimotor-related  issues  Are mealtimes calm or stressful?(31) -Mealtimes might be stressful as a result of feeding issues, or feeding issues might arise due to stressful mealtimes in the child’s household(31) -If the parent reports that mealtimes are usually or always stressful, further investigation into the source of stress is necessary(31) -SLPs can provide education to caregivers regarding strategies that might reduce mealtime stress and improve the child’s feeding and/or swallowing(31) Has the child lost weight over the past 23 months? Has the child’s weight gain slowed significantly in the past 23months?(3) Does the child display signs of respiratory distress during or after a meal or feeding?(3) -Coughing or choking -Difficulty catching his or her breath(3) -Sounding congested(3) -Turning blue -Wet voice(3) Does the child vomit consistently?(3) -If so, when? During or after meals? -What is the amount/consistency? -Children who regularly vomit might be experiencing GERD; referral to gastroenterologist is appropriate for further workup(3) Is there a history of any of the following? -Cardiovascular disease(3) -Central nervous or neurological disorders(3) -Cleft lip and/or palate(3) -Congenital or other abnormalities affecting anatomy or physiology of the oral motor mechanism, pharynx, larynx, or esophagus(3) -Developmental delay -Disorders that affect hunger or appetite, digestion, or food-seeking  behaviors(3) -Enteral feedings -Inflammatory disorders or mucosal infections(3) -Prolonged hospitalizations -Respiratory tract disorders(3)

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Does the patient have a history of oropharyngeal dysphagia or GERD?(18) For older children, were there problems relating to feeding as an infant or young child?
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient or parent/caregiver about other symptoms the patient is experiencing (including weight loss)

social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -With whom does the child live?(e.g., caregivers, siblings)(15) -With whom does the child typically eat?  -What is the child’s typical eating schedule? -Who prepares the child’s food? -What is the child’s typical eating environment? (in front of the TV , grazing, with family members/classmates) -Children with dysphagia might need to eat their meals alone or in silence to prevent distraction, which might increase risk of aspiration -Is the patient receiving nutritional supplements orally or nonorally? -Is there a feeding tube present?(15)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Older children with extremely large girth might not fit into the fluoroscopy chair; refer to radiology department for height, weight, and girth measurement limitations
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: A patient requiring ventilator support might be a candidate if he or she is able to be transported with a portable ventilator(17)
ICU and telemetry patients (i.e., medically unstable patients) should be accompanied to the procedure by a nurse •Motor function (motor control/tone/learning)

For older infants and children, is the child able to sit up and hold up his or her head?(3,6,8,15) -The child should be able to sit up as close to 90° upright as possible during feeding -If the child is unable to sit independently, is repositioning possible using pillows, wedges, or an adaptive chair?
Is the head, neck, and trunk control appropriate for the age of the child?(3)

If the child or parent is unable to maintain proper positioning, the patient might not be appropriate for oral nutrition(6) •Oral mechanism exam and related tests:  An extensive oral mechanism examination should be completed as part of every MBSS.(3,5,19) The oral mechanism exam should include:

Buccal/facial muscles:  Abnormalities of the buccal and facial muscles might indicate damage to cranial nerve (CN) VII(3,15) -Is the face symmetrical at rest? -Is the face symmetrical while making movements (smiling, raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes)? -Are there any abnormal movements (e.g., twitching, spasms, grimacing)? -Is the patient able to manage his or her secretions?(8) -Is the patient’s facial sensation intact?(15) -The patient needs to have adequate sensation of the facial muscles to feel and retrieve any residue during a meal  -Is the patient drooling or mouth breathing?(3,8,15) -Drooling past the age of 5 years is abnormal and requires a comprehensive workup(3) -Refer to otolaryngologist and neurologist -For detailed information about drooling, see  Clinical Review ... Drooling  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708632 -Does the patient present with slurred speech/dysarthria?(15,20) -If child presents with dysarthria, he or she might be appropriate for a full speech/language evaluation following completion of the MBSS -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

Lips:  Abnormalities of the labial muscles might indicate damage to CN VII(3,5,15) -Are the lips symmetrical at rest? -Are the lips symmetrical during movements? -Is ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to completely seal his or her lips during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly(19) -Is the strength normal? -Is the lip tissue healthy? -Is there any scarring or cleft? -Is the patient’s labial sensation intact?(15) -If a patient has reduced sensation of either or both lips, the patient is at risk for anterior loss or pocketing of the food on the side of reduced sensation

Tongue:  Abnormalities of the tongue might indicate damage to CN XII(3,5,15) -Is the tongue normal in appearance? -Any atrophy? -Any tremors present? -Any discolorations? -Any bleeding? -Is ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to reach his or her tongue to the hard palate during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly -Is the strength normal? -If the patient presents with one-sided  weakness of tongue (or lips), he or she is more likely to have food become lodged or pocketed in the oral cavity on the weaker side -Following food and liquid trials, examine weaker side of the oral cavity for residue

Mandible:  Abnormalities of mandibular function might indicate damage to CN V(15) -Is the patient able to maintain jaw closure at rest? -Is ROM normal? -Adequate mandibular ROM is necessary for the patient to adequately masticate solid foods -Is strength normal? -Is the mandible structurally intact? -Patients with head and neck cancer (especially base of tongue cancers) might have had reconstructive surgeries, altering anatomy of the jaw
Hard palate  (3,5) -Is the hard palate intact? -Any signs of fistulas, fissures, scarring? -Are the height and width normal? -Any prostheses present? -Is the coloration normal?

Soft palate (velum):  Abnormalities of the soft palate (velum) might indicate damage to CN XII(3,5,15) -Is the coloration normal (should be pink and white)? -Any signs of cleft or bifid uvula?  -Does the palate elevate sufficiently and equally? -Use a flashlight to see to the back of the patient’s throat during sustained phonation of the syllable /a/ and repeated phonation of /a-a-a/(15) -Does the patient sound hyper-  or hyponasal during conversational speech? -Place a small mirror under the patient’s nose during production of nonnasal sounds; if fogging or clouding occur, this might indicate nasal emission, which would indicate a referral to the otolaryngologist

Oral reflexes  (3) -Rooting reflex:  Present in infants; infant should automatically turn his or her face toward a tactile stimulus and make sucking/rooting motions with the mouth when the cheek or lip is touched -Sucking reflex:  For infants; abnormalities of sucking might indicate damage to CN VII(3) -Does the infant have an appropriate/coordinated sucking reflex?(13) -Premature infants might have difficulty coordinating sucking reflex with breathing(13) -Is the strength of the sucking reflex adequate? -An infant with a weak or uncoordinated sucking reflex might not be able to meet his or her nutritional needs by nipple (breast or bottle) feedings alone(3) -Note during nonnutritive (pacifier/thumb) sucking and nutritive sucking -If the infant is unable to coordinate sufficient nonnutritive sucking, it is unlikely that he or she will be able to coordinate the suck, swallow, and breathing responses adequately with formula or breast milk(3)

Teeth  (5,19) -Are there any missing teeth? -Are the teeth in good repair? -Does the child have orthodontia? -Is there a significant over-  or underbite? •Parent and child interactions:  (3) Observe the parent and infant/child interactions prior to introduction of food or liquid
Children with feeding disorders often present with a behavioral component(3)

If parent and child interactions are strained or stressful, refer to a behavioral specialist for further assessment and intervention function -If aspiration occurs, the SLP should attempt different consistencies to determine if this eliminates aspiration (i.e., if patient aspirates thin liquids, attempt slightly or mildly thick liquids)(17) -Strategies that can be attempted during this time in the study might include: -Altering position (especially for an infant; the mother can change the way in which she is holding the child during feedings)(13) -Alteration of bolus temperature (hot, cold, room temperature), texture, or volume (increasing or decreasing the amount)(13) -Alternating solids and liquids(17) -Chin down(17) -Appropriate for patients with delay of pharyngeal swallow, reduced tongue base retraction, reduced laryngeal closure, or reduced laryngeal elevation(17) -Chin up(17) -Appropriate for patients with tongue dysfunction including poor anterior-posterior propulsion of bolus(17) -Downward pressure with the spoon on the tongue body to assist initiation of swallow response -Dry swallows(17) -Having the patient swallow multiple times to clear as much residue as possible  -Effortful swallow(17) -A maneuver intended to improve tongue base retraction and reduce residue buildup in the valleculae -Head turn to right or left (rotate head towards the damaged side)(17) -Appropriate for patients with unilateral pharyngeal wall weakness, unilateral reduced laryngeal closure, or unilateral vocal fold paresis(17) -Attempt head turn to both sides to increase pharyngeal pressure in patients with cricopharyngeal dysfunction or reduced anterior movement of the larynx(17) -Liquids given by spoon only -Lying down position (on patient’s back or side)(17) -Appropriate for patients with reduced laryngeal elevation or bilateral pharyngeal wall weakness -Mendelsohn maneuver(17) -A technique that aims to improve laryngeal elevation and cricopharyngeal opening; patient is instructed to begin to swallow and “hold” his or her swallow halfway through at the point of maximal laryngeal elevation -Substitute bottle nipple(13) -For bottle-fed  infants, the SLP can attempt various nipple sizes, shapes, and flowrates (i.e., fast flow, slow flow) to increase swallowing safety and eliminate aspiration(13) -Supraglottic swallow maneuver(17) -In this maneuver, the patient is instructed to close the vocal folds via purposeful breath hold before and during the swallow to prevent aspiration -Super supraglottic swallow maneuver(17) -In this maneuver, the patient is instructed to close the entrance to the airway (laryngeal vestibule) before and during the swallow via forceful breath hold to prevent aspiration -For detailed information regarding treatments and strategies used in dysphagia therapy, refer to the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: (3) Conduct a brief assessment of infant/child sensory stimulation, including tactile stimulation (light touch, normal touch, sensitivity to temperatures/pain), visual stimulation, auditory stimulation, and olfactory stimulation –Children might have difficulty with certain textures or temperatures of foods due to sensory integration deficits(3) –Refer to neurologist and/or occupational therapist if the child/infant appears hypo-  or hypersensitive to sensory stimulation
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Desensitization prior to feeding trials  (17) -To adequately prepare a child for the MBSS, the SLP should tell him or her in simple terms what is about to occur during the test(17) -Prior to giving the child barium, food, or liquid trials, the SLP should present the child with an empty spoon and allow him or her to handle the spoon and place it in his or her mouth(17) -This process is intended to reduce oral hypersensitivity or defensiveness prior to the introduction of food trials(17) -For children who are especially fearful or orally defensive, the SLP might want to begin desensitization of the mouth prior to placing the spoon in the child’s mouth -Begin by telling the child “I am going to just touch your face” and lightly touch the jaw(17) -Slowly increase the area of touch as well as the pressure of the touch as the child becomes more comfortable(17)  -Do not feed a child or infant when he or she is upset or crying; this will only serve to reinforce a child or infant’s negative feelings toward feeding(17) –Fluoroscopic oral/pharyngeal examination -The fluoroscopic tube should be aimed toward the patient’s oral cavity and pharynx -In the lateral (side) view, the oral structures (lips, tongue, teeth), the lower rim of the mandible, hyoid bone, epiglottis, laryngeal vestibule, aryepiglottic folds, vallecula, and base of tongue are visible(22) -During the examination, the SLP might ask the patient to face the fluoroscopic tube for an anterior-posterior fluoroscopic view(22) -In the anterior-posterior  view, the oral cavity, tongue, and larynx as well as both the right and left pyriform sinuses and trachea are visible; this view is utilized to determine swallowing symmetry(22) -Prior to giving the patient trials of food and liquid, examine the patient’s swallowing anatomy at rest(1,22) -Is the anatomy of the lips, tongue, tongue base, pharyngeal walls, velum, nasopharynx, pharyngeal walls, larynx, pyriform sinuses, trachea, or esophagus altered in any way? -Are there surgical changes to any aspects of the patient’s anatomy? -When the patient is in the anterior-posterior view, instruct the patient to breathe normally and phonate(1) -Do the vocal folds/arytenoids move symmetrically? –Trials of barium, food, and liquid -The majority of an MBSS is the administration of barium, food, and liquid trials -Any trial given during an MBSS should be either completely comprised of barium or food and liquid mixed with barium -Only barium or food/liquid mixed with barium will be visible as contrast on the MBSS -Parents or caregivers are sometimes more successful when providing trials with children than the SLP(17) -Ensure that parents/caregivers who are providing trials are wearing appropriate lead-lined  gloves and apron per radiation safety protocols(17) -Barium, food, and liquid trials might be given via bottle, spoon, cup sips, or syringe as needed(4) -Trials should be presented in a manner that is most comfortable for the infant child, replicating the home environment as much as possible(17) -Adaptive or “sippy” cups might be used as appropriate with children(17) -For bottle-fed  children, the parent/caregiver should be asked to bring the empty bottle as well as a bottle of formula or breast milk; liquid barium is added for the MBSS trials(17) -A balance of one-third  liquid barium and two-thirds  formula/breast milk allows for adequate contrast for the MBSS while maintaining the taste of the formula for the child(17) -For children who eat solid foods, ask the parent to bring the child’s favorite baby food/pureed food and mix with a ratio of one-third barium and two-thirds  food for trials(17) -Refer to specific clinic/hospital protocol for specifics regarding barium, food, and liquid trials -Begin with small volumes for initial trials (3–5 mL) and progress to larger volumes (10–20 mL)(23) -Many different trials should be administered during an MBSS to most clearly define a patient’s dysphagia(23) -Terminating an MBSS too early might not give the SLP an accurate picture of a patient’s ability to swallow(23) -In a study of adult patients that compared the results of MBSS examinations administered to 42 acute stroke patients and 25 healthy, age-matched peers, using a single measure or liquid volume to define a patient’s swallowing ability did not distinguish between healthy and stroke patients(23) -When the researchers used a variety of measurements and liquid volumes to identify dysphagia in adult patients, more clearly defined swallowing disorders became apparent(23) -Liquids -Thin barium/thin liquid/formula/breast milk mixed with barium(1,18) -Slightly thick barium/slightly thick liquid mixed with barium(32) -Mildly thick barium/mildly thick liquid mixed with barium(32)  -Moderately thick barium/moderately thick liquid mixed with barium(32) -Solids -Extremely thick barium/puree/baby food mixed with barium(33) -Soft solids mixed with or coated in barium(33) (soft fruit, cooked vegetables, soft bread, pasta) -Regular solids,as indicated by developmental ability,coated in barium(33)(crackers/cookies) -During barium, food, and liquid trials, the SLP observes both the patient and the fluoroscopy to evaluate the patient’s swallowing function(1) -Does the patient have difficulty taking the bolus from the bottle, spoon, or cup?(15) -If significant amounts of barium, food, or liquid escape from the patient’s mouth while attempting to eat or drink, adaptive cups and/or utensils might be necessary(18) -Is the patient able to keep the bolus in his or her mouth?(15) -Does the patient effectively swallow his or her saliva?(4) -Following the initial barium, food, or liquid trials, a thin coating of barium will remain and mix with saliva; the SLP can then ask the patient to swallow his or her saliva and observe for aspiration(4) -Does the patient have an appropriate suck-swallow  response?(3) -Is the suck-swallow  response strong and coordinated? -Typically, an infant should have three or fewer sucks per swallow when feeding from a nipple(3) -Is mastication of the solid foods adequate and efficient?(15,18) -If the patient is using more energy to chew the food than he or she is getting from the food itself, solid foods might not be appropriate -Does the patient continue to chew/manipulate bolus until the swallow is complete, or does he or she stop too early, leaving the bolus in the oral cavity?(24) -If the patient does not persist with bolus formation and anterior-posterior  propulsion of the bolus, he or she might not be appropriate for oral nutrition -When a bolus is left in the oral cavity during the meal, the patient is at risk of aspirating this bolus at a later point in time -If a significant portion of the bolus is left in the patient’s oral cavity, note the area of the oral cavity in which the bolus is left -Does the patient trigger and complete the pharyngeal swallow in a timely manner?(19,24) -In older children, if the bolus passes the posterior faucial arches and rests at the base of the tongue, in the valleculae, pharynx, or pyriform sinus without triggering a pharyngeal swallow response, this is considered a delay of the pharyngeal swallow response(24) -Pharyngeal transit time is generally less than 1 second in normal swallowing; significantly increased pharyngeal transit time might indicate pharyngeal wall weakness or reduced pharyngeal pressures(24) -For infants, residue or collection of the bolus in the pyriform sinuses prior to swallow onset might be considered a delay of pharyngeal swallow with an increased risk of aspiration(14) -Patients with very impaired swallow function might not be able to initiate a pharyngeal swallow at all(18) -Does the patient require multiple swallows per bolus?(18) -Multiple swallows generated when a patient is attempting to clear residue from the valleculae, pharyngeal walls, and/ or pyriform sinuses might indicate weakness of the tongue base, pharyngeal walls, and/or cricopharyngeal muscle, respectively -Keep the fluoroscopic tube aimed at the oral cavity and pharynx throughout the examination; after each swallow the radiologist should turn the fluoroscope back on to observe for presence of residue in oral and pharyngeal cavities(4) -If there is residue, is the patient able to clear the residue independently?(4) Patients who require multiple verbal or visual cues and/or a liquid wash to clear residue are at an increased risk of aspiration -Does the barium, food, or liquid enter the patient’s nasal cavity?(24)  -This occurs due to poorly coordinated or reduced velopharyngeal closure(14,24) -Children with a history of cleft palate might present with nasal penetration -Trace nasopharyngeal reflux is not atypical in a preterm infant or a typically developing infant’s first few weeks of life(14) -Does the barium, food, or liquid enter the patient’s laryngeal vestibule? -This is referred to as laryngeal penetration(24) -Deep supraglottic penetration to the lower portion of the laryngeal vestibule is predictive of aspiration in children with risk factors for dysphagia(14) -Does the patient independently clear the penetrated material? -If the patient does not independently clear the penetrated material, is he or she able to clear the penetrated material given a cue?(24) -Does the patient present with aspiration?(1,18,24) -How much of the bolus is aspirated (what percentage)? -Does the patient cough the aspirated material out of the trachea? -Is the aspiration “silent”? -If the patient silently aspirates, is he or she able to clear the aspirated material given a cue to cough or clear his or her throat? -Zenker’s diverticulum(24) -Zenker’s diverticulum is a pocket formed as a result of a herniated pharyngeal or esophageal muscle at the level of the cricopharyngeal muscle(24) -Zenker’s diverticulum might appear directly above or below the cricopharyngeal muscle(24) -If this is noted during the MBSS, refer patient to gastroenterologist for further management -Anterior-posterior  view -When the patient swallows barium trials, observe in the anterior-posterior  view to assess swallowing symmetry(1) -In normal swallowing, the bolus moves through the pharynx and is propelled into the pharynx in two relatively equal halves (with one half of the bolus propelled to each side of the pharynx simultaneously) -If the bolus does not pass on one side of the larynx/pyriform sinuses, this might indicate weakness on this particular side –Trial of compensatory strategies -Once dysphagia is identified via the MBSS, it is appropriate for the SLP to guide the patient through different compensatory strategies in order to determine which strategies are the most beneficial for the patient’s swallowing
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, and cognition should be evaluated by the SLP prior to bringing the patient to the radiology department for the MBSS –For infants, is the alertness and ability to arouse appropriate given the infant’s age?(44) -A calm, alert state is desirable for feeding(44) -Stress cues (e.g., back arching, yawning, crying) are indications that an infant is not ready for oral feeding at the moment(44) -Attempt to schedule the MBSS during a time when the infant would normally be hungry/feeding –Children who are unable to maintain alertness and adequate arousal level might not be appropriate for oral nutrition and medication –Method of communication(15) -Prior to the MBSS, it is appropriate to conduct a brief screening of the patient’s speech and language abilities(19) -It is important that an older child is able to communicate to the SLP during the MBSS -Children should be able to follow verbal or nonverbal commands and/or be compliant with MBSS procedure/ acceptance of barium trials -If the child speaks a different language from that of the SLP, ensure that a certified medical translator (not the child’s family member) is present for the MBSS –Does the child/infant have appropriate self-regulation/self-calming  abilities?(3)
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve; for detailed information on assessment of tracheostomy tube and use of a speaking valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir  Tracheostomy & Ventilator Swallowing and Speaking Valve , referenced above. ForChildren with Tracheostomy , referenced above

contraindications precautions: Types of dysphagia diagnosed by an SLP: oral dysphagia, pharyngeal dysphagia, or oropharyngeal dysphagia(12) -If the SLP suspects an esophageal dysphagia, a referral to gastroenterology is appropriate for further management

Severity of dysphagia: mild, moderate, severe, profound -Mild:  Delay of pharyngeal swallow between 2 and 3 seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are spontaneously cleared; patient coughs appropriately to pharyngeal residue(12) -Moderate:  Delay of pharyngeal swallow between 3 and 5 seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are cleared given a cue; patient coughs to laryngeal penetration or pharyngeal residue given a cue(12) -Severe:  Delay of pharyngeal swallow between 5 and 10 seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are not able to be cleared; patient does not cough appropriately to laryngeal penetration or pharyngeal residue; patient also might have difficulty managing his or her own secretions(12)  -Profound:  Term usually reserved for patients who present with no apparent swallow response, as well as minimal ability to protect the airway

Patients do not always fit into these categories of dysphagia severity; it is also appropriate for the SLP to classify a patient’s dysphagia with the labels minimal, mild-moderate, and moderate-severe(12)

Is the infant/child safe to have strictly oral feedings?(3) -If “yes,” are compensatory strategies necessary?(3) -If “no,” is the child safe to have any oral feedings? -What foods/liquids are safe for the child? -What compensatory strategies are necessary? -Refer to nutrition services regarding supplemental nutrition
What foods and liquids are safe/recommended for the infant/child?
The recommendations for oral feeding are generally based on the severity of dysphagia and overall risk of aspiration(12)

Recommendations -Normal swallow:  If the patient appears to have normal swallowing function, he or she is safe for all consistencies of food and liquid(12) -Minimal impairment:  If the patient appears to have minimally impaired swallowing function, he or she is safe for all consistencies of food and liquid with the independent use of one or more compensatory strategies(12) -Mild impairment:  If the patient appears to have mildly impaired swallowing function, he or she is usually safe for all consistencies of food and liquid with the use of one or more compensatory strategies; an older child would require cueing up to 10% of the time to appropriately incorporate compensatory strategies(12) -Mild-moderate  impairment:  If the patient appears to have mild to moderately impaired swallowing function, he or she will require some modification of diet and will require the use of one or more compensatory strategies; an older child would require cueing up to 25% of the time to appropriately incorporate compensatory strategies(12) -Moderate impairment:  If the patient appears to have moderately impaired swallowing function, he or she will require modification of diet as well as direct supervision during meals; patient will require frequent cues to use one or more compensatory strategies during meals; this type of patient might require nonoral nutritional or hydrational support(12) -Moderate-severe  impairment:  If the patient appears to have moderately severe impaired swallowing function, he or she will require significant modification of diet as well as 1:1 assistance during meals with constant cues to use compensatory strategies during meals; this type of patient will require nonoral nutritional or hydrational support(12) -Severe impairment:  If the patient appears to have severely impaired swallowing function, he or she should be made NPO (nothing by mouth) with nonoral means of nutritional and hydrational support; any food or liquid trials should be given by the SLP only during therapy sessions(12) -Profound impairment:  Patients with a profound impairment of swallowing will not be appropriate for any food, liquid, or medication by mouth; patient is generally not appropriate for therapeutic trials of food or liquid; the patient’s oral
cavity should be aggressively cleaned and suctioned by nursing every 23 hours to prevent infection
For detailed information on dysphagia therapy, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
other: Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Patients with the diagnosis of dysphagia might be at risk for aspiration. Swallowing precautions/feeding guidelines should be posted at bedside and caregivers, family members, and nursing staff should be educated regarding patient’s risk of aspiration ›Diagnosis/results of assessment:  Following an MBSS, the SLP will state whether or not the child has dysphagia.(18) Generally, the SLP will make a statement regarding the type and severity of dysphagia.(12) If the patient does present with dysphagia, the SLP will also make a statement and recommendation regarding oral feedings as well as expected treatment plan(12,18)
Treatment plan:  Treatment plan might include recommendations for direct, indirect, compensatory, or facilitative dysphagia therapy
contraindications precautions.general: Following an MBSS, the SLP will state whether or not the child has dysphagia.(18)

prognosis: Pediatric dysphagia is a multifaceted disorder that requires input from many different medical and therapeutic professionals
Many hospitals and clinics staff and train a pediatric feeding team (with SLP, PT, OT, psychologist, gastroenterologist, otolaryngologist, dietician) for this reason
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for the successful treatment of dysphagia(5,13) Referral to gastroenterologist for children in whom GERD or esophageal dysphagia is suspected(5,19) Referral to neurologist for children with dysphagia who do not have a known underlying diagnosis(5) Referral to pulmonologist for children who appear to have poor respiratory status and/or function(5) Referral to psychologist or behavioral specialist for children in whom behavioral feeding difficulties are suspected(3,13)  Referral to otolaryngologist for children who present with ear, nose, or throat anatomical or physiological abnormalities or if there is apparent vocal fold dysfunction(14) Referral to nutrition services/dietician for children with poor oral intake or those at risk for malnutrition(5,13,25) Referral to physical and/or occupational therapy for children with poor posture; abnormal head, neck, or trunk control; difficulty sitting up in the bed or chair or difficulty feeding themselves(5,13) See Description, Indications of device/equipment  and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above .
